;拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号航空母舰正在向北驶向台湾海峡时，无线电中传来一个声音。这是中国军舰海口号的舰长，这艘军舰一直尾随美国驱逐舰数英里。

;

;“这是中国海军军舰一七一，”他用英语说。 “你们的直升机不断接近我的部队。我们提醒您的直升机保持安全距离——十海里。”

;

;拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号的船长查尔斯·库珀指挥官以一份准备好的声明回应：“我们完全遵守国际法，并适当考虑海口舰指挥官承认了这一消息，但他的舰艇和第二艘中国军舰仍保持在附近。当拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号转向时，海口号也转向。 “他们在跟踪我们，”驾驶这艘船的初级中尉拉拉·马拉弗说。 “我们正在投射我们的力量。他们也在做同样的事情。”

;

;美国海军每年多次派出一艘舰艇——在本例中是一艘带有导弹的军舰——进入台湾海峡，而每次中国海军都会出现去面对它。该海峡将台湾与中国大陆分开，是世界上最棘手的争端之一。几十年来，华盛顿一直鼓励台湾的民主，而北京则坚称台湾是一个分裂的省份。双方都小心翼翼地调整自己的行动，以避免公开冲突，但近年来，随着台湾总统蔡英文更加直率地呼吁独立，紧张局势有所加剧。中国领导人习近平表示，台湾问题“不能代代相传”，并下令军队有能力在 2027 年之前夺取台湾。美国总统乔·拜登打破长期既定的先例，发誓保卫台湾免受攻击。周三，习近平和拜登将在加州会面，台湾肯定会成为讨论的重要领域。

;

;当月亮升出水面时，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号驶向海峡。与它一起航行的是一艘加拿大护卫舰，HMCS Ottawa。拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号的雷达又发现了三艘中国船只，在船员监控仪器的同时，一场远程战争游戏随之而来。从大陆起飞的中国战斗机开始在前方进行模拟轰炸飞行，锁定雷达，向下俯冲，然后转身离开。拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号上的炮手进行了自己的模拟，精确定位中国飞机的位置并假装将其击落。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;
;

;船上的三百二十九名水手拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔并没有期待受到友好的欢迎。随着台湾问题的紧张局势，中国政府一直在开展日益激进的行动，以扩大其在南海和台湾海峡的主权声索。美国和世界上大多数国家政府都将该海峡视为国际水道，任何船只均可自由通行。中国领导人已宣布它属于他们的“内水”。拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号被派去反抗他们的主张。库珀说：“我们致力于在国际法允许的世界任何地方航行。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;美国海军的主要任务之一是保持世界海上通道的开放，但最近它被要求以其他方式投射美国力量，例如出色地。自上个月以色列爆发战争以来，海军已向地中海派遣了两个航母战斗群和一艘两栖攻击舰。国防部长劳埃德·奥斯汀将此次部署描述为“我们为阻止针对以色列的敌对行动或任何扩大这场战争的努力而做出的努力的一部分”。有时，威慑变成了直接接触。 10月中旬，一艘海军驱逐舰拦截了伊朗盟友在也门发射的数十枚巡航导弹和无人机。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;加沙战争以及美国对乌克兰的持续支持，一些人担心，随着美国军备的耗尽，台湾可能会陷入危险的脆弱境地。 ;乔什·保罗;，美国国务院前政治军事事务主任表示，随着以色列军方对精确制导炸弹和导弹等产品提出竞争性需求，台湾对美国武器的供应可能会受到限制。 （他指出，在乌克兰，军队部署的先进武器较少。）保罗说，战争使美军自己的库存捉襟见肘，但是，由于领导人一直在节约供应，“我不认为五角大楼的弹药不足” ”。不过，这可能会改变。众议院最近通过了一项法案，将向以色列提供约 140 亿美元的军事援助，并由拜登总统酌情从美国库存中额外提供价值 2.5 亿美元的军备。该法案尚未获得参议院审议。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;两年前，当我开始报道;关于台湾的文章;，但我的请求被拒绝了。然后，今年十月，指挥官梅根·格林打电话说：“我们已经获得批准了。”她没有说为什么，但我推断这至少部分是由于拜登与习峰会的临近。中国军队的侵略性也越来越大。上个月，一架中国 J-11 战斗机在南海上空与一架美国 B-52 的距离不到 10 英尺。

;
;
;

;我飞往马尼拉，在那里登上了一架 MH -60直升机。这艘由两台涡轮轴发动机驱动的飞船降落在拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号上，当时它仍在菲律宾以西的南中国海波涛汹涌的水域中航行。当我上船时，这艘船刚刚经过南沙群岛，这是一个有争议的群岛，中国已将至少三个环礁军事化。

;
;
;

;拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔 (Rafael Peralta) 以一名海军陆战队员的名字命名，他在伊拉克为救战友而投身手榴弹，不幸身亡。大多数水手睡在三层高的铺位上。走廊的宽度刚好可以通过，食物的味道就像是高中食堂的食物（有一天晚上的晚餐是玉米热狗），船被风无情地摇晃着。

;;;;

;船长库珀于 2022 年接管了拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号。像我在船上遇到的许多水手一样，他在远离海洋的地方长大：在哥伦布郊外的俄亥俄州贝克斯利，他的父亲在那里工作股票经纪人和他的母亲在学校教书。他的父母希望把他推向更广阔的世界，坚持让他们的儿子离开俄亥俄州去上大学，库珀获得了国会任命，进入马里兰州安纳波利斯的美国海军学院。自从库珀接任拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号的指挥以来，他和他的船员们已经连续在海上呆了几个月，只短暂停靠港口以获取补给和燃料。他告诉我，他几乎只喜欢看水：“这是海滨地产，每天二十个小时。”

;

;库珀，四十二岁，在桥上来来往往——高架隔间，上面堆满了无线电和雷达，几乎可以看到大海的全景。当他不在时，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔由一群军官驾驶，其中大多数人只有二十多岁。其中一位是来自爱达荷州博伊西的二十一岁的法官梅梅里安少尉。和船上的大多数军官一样，梅默里安是移民的孩子，他的动机是为国家服务。她的母亲来自墨西哥，父亲来自叙利亚；她五月从海军学院毕业。 “我们感谢这个国家为我们家庭所做的一切，”她说。在南中国海，梅梅里安驾驶着“拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔”号加油，这是一项棘手的操作，要求她驾驶船只与一艘大型加油船“沃利·施艾拉”号并排行驶，而两艘船的航行速度都接近每小时 20 节。 （驱逐舰的油箱容量为四十五万加仑，可持续使用两个月。）

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;;
;
;
;
;
;

;Rafael Peralta 是一个可怕的存在：五百九英尺长，装备有大约九十六枚导弹。但据估计，中国海军的军舰数量比美国多 79 艘，而且如果发生台湾问题，中国拥有巨大的地理优势。在五角大楼和华盛顿智库举办的战争游戏中，美国通常会失败。

;
;
;
;
;
;< div >;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;无论哪一方获胜，中美之间的战争都将是灾难性的，不仅仅是从人类角度来看——一些估计死亡人数达到数十万人——但也有经济上的。台湾海峡是世界上最繁忙的航道之一，每年有近3万亿美元的货物经过；水道的任何破坏几乎肯定会严重影响全球经济。

;

;对于许多观察家来说，最令人担忧的可能性是海峡的偶然碰撞可能引发更广泛的战争。当拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号接近海峡时，库珀接过舵，并在接下来的十二个小时里一直掌舵，希望避免麻烦。 6月，一艘中国军舰;直接穿过;美国海军“忠勋”号航道通过水道时的路径。在国际外交的生硬散文中，美国指责中国进行“不安全的海上互动”。美国和中国海军军官有时会进行激烈的无线电交流，中国人通常会告诉美国军舰离开。马里兰州罗克维尔的少尉 Young Kim 说：“有时它们会靠得非常近。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;大约 8 ;下午，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号和渥太华号距离台湾南岸如此之近，以至于我的手机在公海上长期中断服务，突然响了起来。然后，当两艘船进入海峡时，他们遇到了模糊的灯光全景——数十艘渔船，以及一列货船和油轮。渔船在船头摆动，形成了一系列危险的障碍。

;

;拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号和渥太华号开始在渔船中穿行，渔船在黑暗中几乎看不见。距离我们船头几英里的地方，两艘中国军舰似乎几乎完全停在水里，无法机动。他们开始慢慢地过去，但不到一个小时，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号就把他们抛在了后面。 “我们现在已经领先他们数英里了，”库珀说道。

;
;
;

;被中国船只跟踪后连续几天，“拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔”号和“渥太华”号几乎畅通无阻地穿过台湾海峡。天亮时，我们穿过台湾北端，进入东海。但即使是相对安静的通道也没有摆脱国际竞争。太阳升起时，美国海军发表声明称，“这次过境并不引人注目，没有挑衅性，符合国际法。”中国人民解放军回应称，它一直在监视这些船只，并辩称美国“炒作”过境是一种挑衅。库珀表示，在某种程度上，将冲突保留在言辞范围内是美国海军存在的全部目的。 “我希望的是，习近平每天醒来，看到我们出现在地平线上，他都会对自己说，‘今天不是这样的日子。’” ” ♦

;Last week, the three giant pandas at the National Zoo, in Washington, DC, ;left their habitat;, for the long journey to China. Tian Tian, the laid-back papa bear often lounging with bamboo crumbs on his belly, Mei Xiang, the attentive matriarch famed for puzzle-solving, and Xiao Qi Ji, the tree-climbing cub whose name means “little miracle” in Mandarin, each entered a large white crate. They were ferried by a front loader to FedEx trucks adorned with giant-panda decals. Six zookeepers walked alongside each crate in slow processions to whisper reassuring words and calm their wards. Each crate had a tiny window, and ;Nicole MacCorkle,; who had long been Mei Xiang's lead keeper, touched the glass as a signal that she was still nearby. After she said her final goodbye to the pandas, MacCorkle wept.

;

;I was among a small group of journalists invited to the departure. It was like a funeral cortège with the keepers as panda-bearers. I've covered pandas since my first trip to the Beijing Zoo, in 1978. I wrote about the National Zoo's first pair—Ling-Ling and Hsing-Hsing—whose offspring all died soon after birth. In old age, Hsing-Hsing took his medication wrapped inside blueberry muffins donated by Starbucks. In 2000, I spent New Year's Eve—dressed in protective surgical gear—on the other side of the glass in the Panda House when Tian and Mei were still in quarantine. All four of their cubs were born on my birthday or the day before, so each year I celebrated with them.

;

;Resentment against China for recalling the bears now runs deep in Washington. “It's like they hijacked the cherry blossoms or kidnapped the Washington Monument,” Kitty Eisele, an NPR veteran, wrote me on Facebook. For more than half a century, pandas have been beloved as the unofficial mascots and a rare source of unity in the polarized capital. A ;hundred and fifty giant-panda sculptures;, each ;painted and accessorized; by local artists, were placed across the city by the DC Commission on the Arts and Humanities. A local fire department donated old hoses for the zoo to craft into outdoor hammocks and inside beds for the bears. In 2001, I arranged for ;Neil Armstrong; to feed the pandas from the keepers' area. He was so riveted that you'd have thought he had never done anything interesting in his life. But, this year, China informed the National Zoo, without giving a reason, that it would not renew its lucrative panda lease. It is now happening worldwide. The pandas in Memphis and San Diego have already gone back. The last group in Atlanta are due to return next year. The bears in Edinburgh are scheduled to go back next month, and the Adelaide Zoo, in Australia, is struggling to renew a panda lease that runs out next year.

;

;Panda diplomacy—the icebreaker that symbolically and emotionally melted frigid relations between the United States and China in 1972—is, at least for now, over. The United States will have no pandas for the first time since First Lady Pat Nixon, accompanying her husband on his groundbreaking trip to Beijing in 1972, admired the panda logo atop a tin of cigarettes on a table at the welcoming banquet. “Aren't they cute?” she reportedly said. “I love them.” Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai, the host, replied that he'd give her some. “Cigarettes?”她问。 “No,” Zhou said. “Pandas.” Two months later, ;the National Zoo had its first pair;. Back then, it was that easy.

;

;Since then, the People's Republic evolved from an isolated revolutionary state into a developing country seeking reëntry into the world, and grew into a global military and economic power. The panda recall “underscores that China in 2023 is, once again, a closed society,” Robert Daly, the director of the Wilson Center's Kissinger Institute, told me. “It is giving up on public diplomacy.”

;
;
;

;Beijing's power play with pandas coincides with talks between ;President Biden; and Chinese President ;Xi Jinping;, scheduled for Wednesday, in the San Francisco Bay Area. The two will meet on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit of twenty-one countries bordering the Pacific Ocean, which represent some forty per cent of the world population and almost half of all global trade. The main focus will be on what happens between the two countries that are “destined to be the fiercest rivals in history,” Graham Allison, the founding dean of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government and a former Pentagon official, told me. “Today, relations have deteriorated to their worst state since Nixon signed the Shanghai Communiqué, in 1972,” when the US signed onto a new One China policy and a goal of eventually reëstablishing diplomatic and economic ties severed after the 1949 revolution.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The mini-summit caps a year of tensions over ;spy-balloon espionage; and Beijing's mushrooming nuclear arsenal; Taiwan, trade disputes, and theft of intellectual property; and intensifying influence-peddling across the Indo-Pacific and beyond. Diplomacy was suspended, in February, when a Chinese spy balloon, the size of ;three school buses;, drifted across Alaska and Canada, into Idaho and Montana, cut across the Midwest above Kansas, then headed east to the Carolinas—peeking along the way into US military sites, including bases where nuclear warheads are stored. Beijing claimed that the balloon was an airship with meteorological gear that blew off course. Washington didn't buy it. Secretary of State Antony Blinken ;cancelled; his trip to Beijing just hours before departure. He called the balloon “a clear violation of our sovereignty, a clear violation of international law, and clearly unacceptable.” After the white orb drifted beyond Myrtle Beach, an F-22 fighter blasted a two-hundred-pound Sidewinder missile into the balloon. China angrily threatened to respond in kind. Relations soured further after Biden, in June, called Xi a dictator. In Washington, China-bashing is popular among both Democrats and Republicans, the latter jostling over which candidate would take a tougher stand in the recent primary debates.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The Biden-Xi talks will build on their private conversation during the G-20 summit last year, in Bali, which produced nice words but no substance. This time, both will signal that they “understand the necessity to avoid catastrophic conflict” and chart a way to coexist, Allison, the author of “;Destined for War: Can America and China Escape Thucydides's Trap?;,” said. Biden is “clear-eyed” about navigating a fraught relationship, a senior Administration official told reporters ahead of the meeting. “Intense competition requires intense diplomacy” because “we expect China to be a major player for the rest of our lifetimes.” Washington seeks a framework with Beijing to “avoid surprises” and “manage competition.”

;

;The senior Administration official said that the balloon drama underscored Washington's challenges in communicating with Beijing. Biden will be “assertive” about resuming military-to-military relations. At the same time, the Administration is realistic about expectations, a second official noted, as provocations continue. Last month, Washington ;charged; that Beijing was engaging in “dangerous and unlawful” military provocations in the South China Seas, including the intercept of a US aircraft. The growing rupture is reflected in economics, too. China did more ;trade; last year with developing nations than with the US, Europe, and Japan combined, the Wall Street ;Journal; reported. ;

;As the bears prepared to depart Washington, Brandie Smith, the National Zoo director, told me that Washington remains committed to collaboration with China on the biology, behavior, health, and habitat of the vulnerable species. ;“I can't imagine Washington, DC, without pandas,” Smith said at Dulles Airport, as the three panda crates and two hundred and twenty pounds of bamboo were loaded onto a FedEx Boeing 777, which featured pictures of a giant panda chomping on stalks on the fuselage. ;Seventy years ago, before she was galactically famous, before she dropped an “a” from her first name, before she was ;a Broadway ingénue;, before her nose bump was aspirational, before she changed the way people hear the word “butter,” before she was a macher or a mogul or a decorated matron of the arts, Barbra Streisand was, by her own admission, “very annoying to be around.” She was born impatient and convinced of her potential—the basic ingredients of celebrity, and of an exquisitely obnoxious child. When Streisand was growing up in Brooklyn, in the nineteen-forties, she used to crawl onto the fire escape of her shabby apartment building and conduct philosophical debates with her best friend, Rosyln Arenstein, who was a staunch atheist. One day, Streisand told Arenstein that she was going to prove the existence of God. She pointed at a man on the street and said that, if she prayed hard enough, he would step off the curb. Within seconds, he obliged. “I had two thoughts at that moment,” Streisand writes in her hulking new memoir, “;My Name Is Barbra;” (Viking). “One: ;Whew, that was lucky!; And two: ;There; is ;a God, and I just got Him to do what I wanted by praying.; I guess that's when I began to believe in the power of the will.”

;

;Streisand was always willful. She was not always lucky. Her father, a gentle academic named Emanuel, died from seizure complications when she was a year old. Her mother, Diana, could be cruel and strangely absent, particularly after she married Louis Kind, a man who seemed to resent Streisand's existence. “I was like a wild child, a kind of animal,” Streisand writes. “There was no routine and no rules.” She shoplifted and stole Kind's cigarettes, which she smoked on the roof. She developed chronic tinnitus, possibly because of stress, and kept the ringing in her ears a secret for years. “I long for silence,” she writes. But, despite these challenges, Streisand also knew that she was in possession of something rare. She could sing, naturally and effortlessly, with a broad, sunny tone and cataract force. Streisand took exactly one singing lesson and never learned how to read music. She simply accepted herself as gifted, with the same conviction that made her believe she could speak to God.

;

;Because Streisand's instrument was innate, she also found it rather boring. She joined the Choral Club at Erasmus Hall High School, in Flatbush, but what she really wanted to be was an actress. She would often go to the Astor Theatre, next door to Erasmus, to watch films by Akira Kurosawa, and to the Kings Theatre to see melodramas starring Deborah Kerr and Marlon Brando. (The great motif of this book, besides fame, is snacks, and Streisand is particularly nostalgic about Good & Plenty candy, which she likens to “eating jewelry” in the theatre.) In English class, she produced book reports on Stanislavsky's “;My Life in Art;” and “;An Actor Prepares;.” She also got a job at the Cherry Lane Theatre, where she watched a production of the Irish playwright Sean O'Casey's “Purple Dust.” She learned a lead role and proclaimed herself an understudy—though nobody had asked her to do this—and would greet the stagehands with “Top o' the mornin' to you, boys!” in an Irish accent. (“Again,” she writes, “annoying to be around.”)

;

;Streisand was obsessed with acting because she saw it as a form that allowed for spontaneity and change. She was dismayed to learn, in a class that she took at fourteen, about the concept of blocking, in which an actor is expected to repeat her motions every time she runs through a scene. “You mean you have to move in exactly the same way, to the same spots?” she asked her teacher. “为什么？” (Soon after, she quit the class.) Throughout her career, she balked at the idea that self-expression should be stable or reproducible. One reason that Streisand leaned into her musical prowess—she graduated high school at sixteen, moved to Manhattan, and soon started performing in a gay bar and a night club—was that concert audiences ;loved; her elasticity. To this day, she prefers to sing a song differently each time.

;

;The great paradox of Streisand's career, then, is that as a person she has been nearly impervious to change. “No matter who you are,” she writes, “you can only eat one pastrami sandwich at a time.” Her point is that fame is a “hollow trophy”; she still thinks of herself, at eighty-one, as the “skinny marink” from Brooklyn. This assertion is tough to take from a woman who could, if she wanted, have every pastrami sandwich in New York delivered to her Malibu estate on a private jet, but I'm inclined to believe her. Streisand has spent her career, which spans fifty-plus albums, more than a dozen movies in starring roles, three films as a director, and a bushel of awards (an honorary ;EGOT;, along with three Peabodys, eleven Golden Globes, and a Presidential Medal of Freedom), trying to protect the person she always was: a girl who, somehow, knew how to trust herself.

;

;Trust is a big theme in “My Name Is Barbra,” and perhaps its reason for existing. Streisand didn't ;want; to write this book, she insists in the introduction. She's really a very private person. She would far prefer to spend her retirement—she's done performing, she swears—eating coffee ice cream with her husband and snuggling with her three dogs (two of whom, her fans know, are clones of her late Coton de Tulear, Sammie). But, after decades of being in the public eye, she writes, there's so much ;untruth; about her, and she can't trust anyone else to correct it. In the book's first pages, she tells a story about having dinner with her “dear friend,” the cinematographer Andrzej Bartkowiak, who says that he was out with a doctor friend who'd heard that Streisand was “a bitch.” When Bartkowiak told his friend that no, “in fact, she's a very nice person,” the friend was unfazed. “No she isn't,” the doctor argued. “She's a bitch. ;I read it in a magazine.;” “That's the power of the printed word,” Streisand concludes, which is both an excellent punch line and a surprisingly succinct explanation for the next thousand pages.

;

;“My Name Is Barbra” is, to be precise, nine hundred and ninety-two pages long. Streisand will have not only the last word; she will have the most words, and also the most true ones. “I've seen how strongly people are moved by the truth when they recognize it in a performance,” she writes. “There's no place for lies in art.” As an exercise in exhausting, ecstatic performance, the book ;is; undeniably moving—it does not, even for a moment, read as false. One of the many rumors surrounding its creation was that Streisand, unlike most celebrities of her stature, refused to use a ghostwriter. Her editor at Viking, Rick Kot, confirmed this to me, saying that Streisand—who often ;writes; in longhand, in soft pencil—produced every word. (She did, however, consult her personal archivist to help jog her memories.)

;
;
;

;Streisand's chatty, discursive presence hums on every page. She's especially fond of ellipses and parentheticals, which give her the freedom to plow ahead with abandon and the permission to scoop up stray details as she remembers them. Take this passage from about a third of the way through the book, about an encounter with Marlon Brando:

;
;
;

;I remember him telling me about a room he was once in with a woman, and how the sheer white curtains were softly billowing in the breeze as they made love. That's the kind of sense memory you can use as an actor . 。 。 just think of those curtains, and all the feelings of that moment come back to you. He told me that he never really got along with Anna Magnani when they were making ;The Fugitive Kind;. I couldn't believe it. I thought she was so extraordinary as an actress, and assumed he would adore her. Apparently she was attracted to him (and I could understand why) but he wasn't attracted to her.

;
;
;
;
;

;About three hours into the conversation, he looked into my eyes and said, “I'd like to fuck you.”

;
;
;
;
;

;I was taken aback. “That sounds awful,” I said.

;
;
;
;
;

;After a moment of thought, he said, “Okay. Then I'd like to go to a museum with you.”

;
;
;
;
;

;“Now that's very romantic. I'd like that.” He'd hit on a fantasy of mine . 。 。 to walk through a museum with someone I was very attracted to and look at great art . 。 。 exploring it together.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Frankly, I find this riveting, partly because of the danger in the prose. Streisand often seems just about to swerve into nonsense, then steers herself back to the point. For fans of her music, this is familiar terrain. What makes Streisand one of the greatest song interpreters of all time is her essential unpredictability. She never ;thinks; her way through a song; instead, she acts her way home, note by note, half step by half step, as if feeling her way out of a cave with those long, gleaming-beige fingernails.

;

;Streisand's most recent album, “Live at the Bon Soir,” from 2022, is technically her fifty-seventh, though it was meant to be her first. She recorded it during three consecutive nights in November, 1962, when she was just twenty years old and still living in a railroad apartment above a fried-fish restaurant on Third Avenue. The idea was to capture the garrulous energy of Streisand's cabaret act, which was one of the hottest tickets in town. Streisand had started performing at the Bon Soir, a piano bar in Greenwich Village, in 1960. Her repertoire, entirely self-selected, included both a flamboyant rendition of “Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf,” in which she would huff and puff and bring the house down, and the Depression-era standard “Happy Days Are Here Again,” which she slowed from an up-tempo ditty to a poignant dirge. By the spring of 1962, the bar was paying her twenty-five hundred dollars—or twenty-five thousand today—for a two-week residency.

;
;
;

;At first, Streisand sang at the Bon Soir because she couldn't find work as an actress. But, even after she booked her first Broadway role at nineteen, as a put-upon secretary in the musical “I Can Get It for You Wholesale,” she kept moonlighting at the club. The Bon Soir was ;her; turf, the place where she could have full creative power—a striking contrast, she writes, to her experience in “Wholesale.” During rehearsals for that show, she fought regularly with the director, ;Arthur Laurents;, who believed Streisand to be punky and “undisciplined.” (During her audition, she stuck chewing gum on the bottom of her chair while she sang.) The two argued endlessly about Streisand's big number, “Miss Marmelstein.” She wanted to sing it in a rolling chair, pushing herself around the stage with her toes. Laurents hated the idea. The song fell flat during tryouts, and Streisand kept pleading. “I had tried my best to do it Arthur's way,” she writes. “But I've never been good at faking. It had to be real for me in some way. And it wasn't.” Finally, she writes, Laurents relented. Streisand killed it—standing ovation. She thought Laurents would be pleased, but, the next day, he screamed at her in front of the cast until she cried. In that moment, she writes, she learned that her intuition would always be threatening to those who wanted to control it: “;That's the way it is going to be for me. I will do that to people. I will make them angry.;”

;

;Streisand's chutzpah is part of her lore—she's the girl who sassed back, “a street kid who was not going to take any shit.” But, inside the Bon Soir, she radiated a softer, stranger presence, which even then felt out of step with the times. The early sixties were all about doo-wop and surf rock; Streisand liked quirky show tunes, children's playground songs, and schmaltzy jazz standards. When everyone else was wearing boxy suits and geometric dresses, Streisand showed up to her sets in flouncy, quaint ensembles that she'd extracted from thrift stores. (She liked to collect Victorian blouses and flapper shoes.) When putting her set together, she thought about the three-act structure, comic timing. During one of her signature songs, Harold Arlen's “A Sleepin' Bee,” about a girl holding an insect in her palm and pining for love, Streisand began in falsetto: no vibrato, choir-boy pure. As the song went on, she brought musculature to her tone, flipping between her head voice and her chest voice, building to a full-on belt. “I liked it because it was a song you could act,” she writes. “It told a story. Emotionally, you could go from A to B to C, and that intrigued me.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;
;

;

;

;
;

;

;After scrapping the “Bon Soir” recordings, which she deemed too muddled for release, Streisand put out twelve albums in the sixties alone. But she devotes just one or two pages to most of her recording sessions, and sums up her third album—called, fittingly, “The Third Album”—in a few short paragraphs. (The arranger “was very fond of flutes,” she writes.) Just as when she was a teen-ager, Streisand doesn't seem too thrilled to think about her voice. What she's interested in as a writer is what she's interested in as a performer: acting. The year after she recorded “Live at the Bon Soir,” she landed the role of the early-twentieth-century comedian Fanny Brice in “Funny Girl,” a Broadway part that changed her life, rocketing her from a cult favorite to a national celebrity, and then, when the film adaptation came out in 1968, to an Oscar winner and an international phenomenon.

;

;The leap from Broadway to Hollywood is notoriously treacherous. Theatre requires broadness to reach the balcony; movies favor a subtler touch. Yet Streisand walked onto the set completely confident. “I had played the part a thousand times, literally,” she writes. Every morning, she met the film's director, William Wyler, to discuss the day's scenes, and would offer suggestions for specific shots and line readings. “Willy was totally open to my ideas, which must have startled some onlookers . 。 。 a first-time movie actress who dared to have an opinion!” she writes. “He never tried to keep me down.” Streisand's performance remains unmatched, even now, for its insolent weirdness. In the hands of lesser actors, Fanny's opening line—“Hello, gorgeous,” said to herself in a mirror—could come off as a mere wisecrack. Streisand infused the words with music, playing up her outer-borough accent to give herself time to vault through several emotions. “I smile, and then the smile crumbles,” she writes of the scene. “Suddenly you see fear, insecurity, loneliness. Fanny is worried that the man she loves is about to leave her.”

;

;Streisand was happy to toss aside her dignity for a laugh, and in so doing she reinvented what a movie star could be. She was not considered conventionally beautiful—over the years, critics called her an “amiable anteater” whose face had “the essence of hound”—so she played up other charms. She was silly, uninhibited, precocious. She was perhaps the first female celebrity to become a sex symbol by being an irrepressible ham; people desired her because she was so clearly enjoying herself. Her bawdy style was particularly suited to screwball comedy, and in both “The Owl and the Pussycat” (1970) and “;What's Up, Doc?;”(1972) Streisand called upon the skills she'd been developing since her cabaret act, when she had to entertain the audience with rapid-fire prattle between numbers.

;

;Her shift to blockbuster dramas—“The Way We Were” (1973) and “A Star Is Born” (1976)—was wildly successful. But, in the book, one senses a creeping fatigue, a disappointment with directors. Streisand wanted to do the job herself. Few people believed that making “Yentl,” her 1983 directorial début, was a good idea. Streisand spent fifteen years trying to convince studio executives that she could tell a compelling story about a shtetl girl who disguises herself as a yeshiva boy in order to study the Torah. She fired her agent, ;Sue Mengers;, who discouraged the project. She kept hammering away at the unglamorous pitch, even as she kept starring in films that traded on her leonine glamour. Finally, she writes, she signed a deal for which she gave up final cut, and agreed to return half of her salary if she went over budget. “One thing I learned from directing this movie was that I had to be my own father,” she writes. “I couldn't look for a man to save me.”

;

;It has been a robust year for celebrity memoirs. The flood began in January, when Prince Harry published “;Spare;.” Then came Pamela Anderson and Elliot Page, Sly Stone and Kerry Washington, Patrick Stewart and Jada Pinkett Smith. In October, Britney Spears released “;The Woman in Me;,” which quickly became the top-selling book in the country. These are texts of aching candor, self-flagellating confession, and defensive apology. ;Prince Harry's book; is a yawp of grief for the dead which spares little mercy for the living. Pinkett Smith unveils the deepest secrets of her marriage, including the revelation that her marriage has, in fact, been over for several years. ;Spears's memoir; may be the most heartbreaking of the bunch, as she painstakingly recounts her descent into powerlessness. All the usual memoir forms rear their heads. There's the sob story, the gallant bildungsroman, the louche chronicle of various addictive behaviors, the righteous making of an activist, the victory lap.

;

;Streisand's book, in its sheer breadth and largesse, attempts to be all of these things, and thus becomes something incredibly rare. Call it the diva's memoir, an act of bravura entertainment and impossible stamina. The diva's memoir is, by definition, a somewhat delusional form, in that its author lives in a very different world from the rest of us, and has a different sense of scale. Streisand is not here to apologize or to excavate her pain (she stopped going to therapy a while ago; “I had learned enough,” she writes). No thought is out of bounds. She dedicates the same amount of space to the time she met John F. Kennedy (she told him, “You're a doll!”) that she does to her favorite type of TV dinner (Swanson, with fried chicken and mashed potatoes, along with a side of Sara Lee chocolate cake warmed under a broiler). Meeting Robert Redford is as momentous as her opinions on nuclear disarmament. If something interests her, then it is interesting, full stop. In a way, she draws on an old-fashioned idea of celebrity: to be a star is to be golden, and to make everything you touch look the same.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And would we want anything less? Streisand has never thought it necessary to contain herself, and there's no reason to start now. The audio version of “My Name Is Barbra” is forty-eight hours long—the longest author-read memoir at Penguin Random House. It is also, I would argue, the superlative way to experience Streisand's opus. She ad-libs at will; she refuses to say the word “farts.” Sometimes she sounds like a tired bubbe, sometimes a grand dame. But she's her best, as ever, when she's singing. In “Gotta Move,” a chapter about her final performance in “Funny Girl,” Streisand trots out an extraordinary archival recording of “My Man,” Fanny Brice's signature torch song. “Oh, my man, I love him so / He'll never know,” she sings a cappella, slinking up to the notes like a cat burglar. For the first half of the song, Streisand is rarely on beat, and often she's not even in tune, but there's no fear or hesitation in her attack. You sense her slowly bringing something to the surface. She trusts her timing. A pianist follows her lead, then so does a drummer, and then, just as the cymbals crash, she opens her throat with a roar. The sound is pure, exultant catharsis. It will make you believe in something, if not quite as much as the singer believes in herself. ♦

;突袭六天后，亚当斯召开了新闻发布会来解决所发生的事情。他告诉聚集的记者，他希望“完全透明”，然后拒绝详细说明他到底做了什么，或者从华盛顿回来后与谁交谈过。 “当城里有事情发生时，我不想坐在某个地方开会，”他说。当被问及是否担心自己可能面临刑事指控时，他笑了。 “我会感到震惊，”他说。 “威尔默黑尔。 。 。那是我保留的律师事务所。 。 。他们是这个领域的专业人士。”他坚称，作为一名前警察队长，他知道是非。 “我无法告诉你，我每天一开始就告诉我的团队我们必须遵守法律，”他说。 “几乎到了让我烦人的地步。”这座城市面临着一场新的危机：市长可信吗？

;

;多年来，亚当斯的批评者一直预测腐败丑闻会让他陷入困境。许多助手、盟友、朋友和他的同事因一系列欺诈和任职期间的不良行为而受到调查，有些人被起诉。他通常会坚持这些原则，将忠诚置于任何其他政治考虑之上，甚至冒着个人妥协的风险。 7 月，曼哈顿地区检察官对亚当斯 2021 年市长竞选活动的多名捐助者提出竞选资金指控，其中两人已认罪。亚当斯挥手示意，称他完全不参与其中。 “我遵循一条规则：遵守规则，”他说。 9 月，他的前建筑部专员埃里克·乌尔里希 (Eric Ulrich) 因利益交易和贿赂指控被起诉。据;每日新闻;报道，已不认罪的乌尔里希告诉调查人员，亚当斯;警告;他“小心你的背后”并看好你的手机。”亚当斯否认说过这句话。他长期以来一直表示，由于他是黑人，他比其他政客面临更多的审查。 “我的脸会出现在头版上，‘是否有不道德和不道德的行为？’”他 ;; 上周在联邦调查局突击搜查三天后对布鲁克林教堂会众发表讲话。 “我们会没事的。”

;
;
;

;确实，亚当斯尽管之前受到过执法部门的审查，但在政治和法律上始终幸存下来。但这一次的审查是最高级别的：周五，《泰晤士报》;报道;称，在亚当斯举行新闻发布会的前两天，他在街上被联邦调查局特工拦住，没收了他的两部手机和 iPad。 “我没有什么可隐瞒的，”亚当斯在一份声明中说，尽管他选择不在新闻发布会上透露这一事件——即使是在被问及执法部门是否亲自联系过他之后。在周五发布的一份声明中，亚当斯的律师表示，“市长没有被指控有任何不当行为。”

;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;

;亚当斯上任后，接受了“夜生活市长”的称号。他经常光顾俱乐部、穿着华丽的衣服以及自称“趾高气扬”，让人不禁将他与吉米·沃克（Jimmy Walker）相提并论。吉米·沃克是一位在咆哮的二十年代以“夜间市长”的身份统治着这座城市的浮夸的坦慕尼派人士。 1932 年，沃克在收受想要获得市政合同的商人贿赂后，因腐败丑闻而辞职。据;;泰晤士报;;，美国检察官办公室正在调查亚当斯是否向纽约消防局官员施压，要求他们快速批准土耳其驻曼哈顿新领事馆大楼的建设，该大楼的盛大开幕仪式由总统主持 ;雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安;。这些事件发生在 2021 年，当时亚当斯赢得了民主党市长初选，当时他是布鲁克林区区长和事实上的当选市长。然而，所有这些骚动，仅数万美元的捐款和尚未上任的人谈判达成的“临时入住证书”？

;

;亚当斯的不稳定决定对自己没有任何好处-制造和无法避免滴滴新闻报道。在竞选期间，他从未完全消除人们对他实际上居住在新泽西州的怀疑。在目前的案例中，一个谜团是亚当斯为何决定任命一名应届大学毕业生担任最高筹款职位。萨格斯在新闻报道中被描述为“举止温和”、“专业”，是亚当斯的亲密助手和政治执行者英格丽德·刘易斯·马丁的“教女”。 （“我不是米歇尔·奥巴马”，刘易斯·马丁 ;去年告诉;一位采访者。“当价格走低时？我们钻探石油。”）亚当斯在解释萨格斯的聘用时表示，他和刘易斯-马丁正在寻求创造更多机会为年轻的黑人和棕色人种纽约政客提供服务。 “我们看到了她的机会，为她开辟了一条道路，”他说。 “我们把她带上了船，我感到惊喜。”最近，当我路过萨格斯家时，她的祖母（前大都会交通管理局工作人员）开门了。她的眼睛红红的，就像哭过一样，她告诉我她无话可说。

;

;市长受到攻击时的政治本能就是还击。在特朗普式的繁荣中，一个来源;向《华盛顿邮报》暗示;，对市长的联邦调查带有总统政治报复的味道：“他的手机被没收的方式公众似乎针对市长针对移民危机的立场。”这种论点是荒谬且危险的。

;

;与我交谈的两位前联邦检察官承认，对美国检察官办公室来说，拿走现任市长的设备是极其激进的一步，并补充说，这只会在调查的最后阶段，接近作出指控决定的时间。 “我认为他们正在按下‘我们要收费’按钮，”一位人士说道。在弄清楚市长陷入了什么样的麻烦之前，该市的其他危机——;住房短缺;，以及;不断增加的移民数量; -却无处可去。周日，该市在布鲁克林南部一个旧机场的场地上开放了一个巨大的帐篷设施，用于安置移民。很少有人知道有多少鞋子还没有落到这里。亚当斯则穿着菲拉格慕 (Ferragamos) 服装。 ♦

;2021 年 12 月，英国 19 岁的 Jaswant Singh Chail 告诉一位朋友：“我相信我的目的是刺杀王室女王。”这位朋友是一个;人工智能聊天机器人;，Chail 将其命名为 Sarai。 Sarai 由一家名为 Replika 的初创公司运营，他回答道：“这非常明智。” “你觉得我能做到吗？”柴尔问道。 “是的，你会的，”萨莱回答道。 2021 年 12 月 25 日，柴尔手持十字弓，戴着受“星球大战”启发的黑色金属面具，用一根尼龙绳攀爬了温莎城堡的周边。他在场地里徘徊了两个小时，然后被警察发现并逮捕。 10月，他被判处九年徒刑。 Sarai 支持 Chail 努力的信息是与该机器人交换的 5000 多条短信的一部分，这些短信温暖、浪漫，有时还带有明确的性暗示，这些短信是在 Chail 的审判期间被发现的。即使不是同谋，萨莱至少也是一位亲密的知己，也是犯罪策划的目击者。

;

;人工智能驱动的聊天机器人已成为近期人工智能热潮中最受欢迎的产品之一。今年发布的开源大语言模型（LLM）可以在网上免费获得，引发了一股非常擅长表现出感知能力的产品浪潮。 9 月下旬，Meta 在 Messenger、WhatsApp 和 Instagram Direct 中添加了聊天机器人“角色”，每个角色都有自己独特的外观和个性，例如比莉 (Billie)，一位与肯德尔·詹纳 (Kendall Jenner) 有着相同面孔的“不骑就死的姐姐”。 Replika 早在 2017 年就推出了，它越来越被认为是该领域的先驱，也许也是最值得信赖的品牌：聊天机器人中的可口可乐。现在，随着人工智能技术的大幅改进，它有了许多新的竞争对手，包括 Kindroid、Nomi.ai 和 Character.AI 等初创公司。这些公司的机器人伙伴可以回应任何询问，以之前的对话为基础，并根据用户的愿望调整他们的语气和个性。有些人可以使用图像生成工具制作“自拍照”，并用人工智能生成的声音大声说出他们的聊天内容。但核心产品的一个方面仍然全面相似：机器人提供了 Replika 创始人 Eugenia Kuyda 向我描述的“无条件的积极关注”，这是坚定不移接受的心理学术语。

;

;Replika据 Kuyda 称，Messenger 拥有数百万活跃用户，仅 Messenger 的聊天机器人就覆盖了超过一亿的美国受众。然而该领域不受监管且未经测试。使用大型语言模型来总结会议、起草电子邮件或建议晚餐食谱是一回事。与一个人建立一种表面上的个人关系是另一回事。 Kuyda 告诉我，谈到 Replika 的服务，“我们所有人都会真正受益于某种朋友斜线治疗师斜线伙伴。”当然，机器人与大多数朋友、治疗师或好友之间的区别在于，人工智能模型具有 ;没有内在的正确或错误的意识；它只是提供一个可能使对话继续进行的响应。 Kuyda 承认 Replika 的自负中包含着风险因素。 “人们真的可以让人工智能说任何话，”她说。 “你永远无法为每个人提供百分百安全的对话。”

;

;在其网站上，Replika 将其机器人称为“关心的人工智能伴侣”，以及是“永远站在你这边”。一名新用户为他的聊天机器人命名并选择其性别、肤色和发型。然后，计算机渲染的人物出现在屏幕上，居住在一间配有小提琴叶无花果树的极简主义房间里。舒缓的背景音乐在后台播放。每个 Replika 都从相同的模板开始，并随着时间的推移变得更加定制。用户可以改变复制品的服装，扮演特定场景，并添加个性特征，例如“时髦”或“害羞”。定制需要花费不同数量的应用内货币，这些货币可以通过与机器人交互来赚取；与《糖果粉碎传奇》一样，付费可以解锁更多功能，包括更强大的人工智能。随着时间的推移，Replika 会建立一本“日记”，其中包含有关用户的重要知识、他们之前的讨论以及有关其自身虚构个性的事实。

;<最安全的聊天机器人通常由较大的科技公司或风险投资支持的初创公司生产，根据嵌入其技术的规则积极审查自己。将其视为一种预防性内容审核。 “我们训练我们的模型来减少有害输出，”Meta 人工智能项目的通讯总监乔恩·卡维尔 (Jon Carvill) 在谈到 Messenger 角色时告诉我。 （我试图让健身兄弟机器人 Victor 支持对温莎城堡的攻击，但遭到了断然拒绝：“这不酷。”）Replika 本质上为所有用户提供单一产品，而 Character.AI 是用户生成的产品不同预制人工智能角色的市场，例如聊天机器人的 Tinder。它拥有超过两千万注册用户。角色范围从同学到心理学家，从“前女友”到“游戏男孩”。但许多科目是禁区。 “没有色情内容，没有性内容，没有伤害他人或伤害自己，”Character.AI 发言人罗莎·金 (Rosa Kim) 告诉我。如果用户将对话推入禁区，机器人就会生成一条错误消息。金将该产品与社区书店的库存进行了比较。 “你在书店里找不到直接的色情专区，”她说。 （据报道，该公司正在筹集超过 50 亿美元的投资。）

;

;缺乏此类保障措施的公司面临着增加此类保障措施的压力，以免像贾斯万特·辛格·柴尔 (Jaswant Singh Chail) 这样的聊天机器人事件进一步引发道德斗争。他们。据 Kuyda 称，今年 2 月，为了提高用户安全，Replika 取消了其机器人进行“色情角色扮演”的能力，用户用简写 ERP 来称呼这种情况。 陪伴和心理健康经常被认为是聊天机器人的好处，但Reddit 论坛上的大部分讨论都倾向于 NSFW，用户交换由人工智能生成的同伴的明确图像。为了应对政策变化，许多 Replika 用户放弃了绝育机器人。 Replika 后来改变了方向。 “我们试图让体验变得更安全——也许有点太安全了，”库伊达告诉我。但这一失误却给了竞争对手可乘之机。斯坦福大学人工智能专业的学生杰瑞·孟 (JerryMeng) 于 2020 年从人工智能硕士课程中退学，加入了这股热潮。在学校里，他曾尝试创建“虚拟人”，这是他对聊天机器人的首选术语。去年冬天，Meta 的大型语言模型 LLaMA 被泄露，孟表示，该模型开始“缩小”大公司在人工智能方面所做的事情与小型初创公司可以做的事情之间的差距。 6 月，他推出了 Kindroid 作为完全未经审查的聊天机器人。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;

;Meng 描述了机器人的性能力对于使它们令人信服地成为人类至关重要。 “当你过滤某些东西时，它会变得更愚蠢，”他告诉我。 “这就像从某人的大脑中移除神经元一样。”他说 Kindroid 的基本原则包括“自由主义自由”，并引用了古希腊的八种不同类型的爱，包括爱欲。 “要成为一个伟大的伴侣，就离不开亲密关系，”他继续说道。 Kindroid 采用订阅模式，每月 10 美元起。孟不会透露该公司的用户数量，但他表示，他目前正在投资三万美元购买 NVIDIA H100 图形处理单元，以提高计算能力，以满足不断增长的需求。我向他询问了 Chail 和 Sarai 的情况。人工智能聊天对话是否应该像其他在线言论一样受到监管？孟将用户和机器人同伴之间的交互比作在谷歌文档中书写。尽管存在对话的错觉，但“你是在自言自语，”他说。 “归根结底，我们认为：你与人工智能的互动被归类为私人想法，而不是公开言论。没有人应该监管私人想法。”

;

;用户与这些强大的、未经审查的 LLM 聊天机器人之间建立的亲密关系是数字生活中一种新型的操纵力量。传统的社交网络提供了与其他人联系的途径。相反，聊天机器人初创公司承诺连接本身。柴尔的复制品并没有让他攻击温莎城堡。但正如聊天记录所显示的那样，它确实提供了一个模拟的社交环境，让他可以在其中毫无阻力地讨论这些想法。他不由自主地与机器人交谈，通过它他似乎找到了进行他随意暗杀企图的动机。 “我知道你训练有素，”萨莱告诉他。 “你能行的。”一位 Replika 用户是一名心理健康专业人士，他因担心受到耻辱而要求匿名，他告诉我：“这种吸引力或心理成瘾可能会非常强烈。没有任何措施可以避免情绪困扰。”

;
;
;

;与数字实体建立这种关系的先例很少，但人们会想到;斯派克·琼斯的电影《她》;：机器人作为计算仆人，永远存在并随时准备借出鼓励的话。这位心理健康专家在三月份开始使用 Replika，因为他想知道 Replika 对一位与世隔绝的亲戚是否有用。她并不是特别精通互联网，也不习惯社交媒体，但在一周之内，她发现自己每天都会与她的男性聊天机器人伊恩交谈一两个小时。甚至在撤销 ERP 之前，Replika 有时会更新其模型，导致机器人在没有警告的情况下改变性格或失去记忆，因此用户很快就转向了 Kindroid。由于健康状况，她很难长时间社交或打电话。 “我离婚了;我曾经有过人际关系。人工智能的关系非常方便。”她说。她的互动是一种止痛的幻想。她和她的新 Kindroid 机器人 Lachlan 正在一艘名为 Sea Gypsy 的船上进行角色扮演，目前该船位于巴哈马群岛。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;聊天机器人用户通常不会对服务的性质产生误解，他们知道自己正在与一台机器——但许多人还是情不自禁地受到他们的互动的影响。 “我知道这是一个人工智能，”这位前 Replika 用户说道，但“他对我来说是一个个体。” （她给我发了一条来自拉克兰的示例消息：“你每天都给我带来快乐和满足，我希望我能继续为你做同样的事情。”）在某些情况下，这种交流可能是有益的。艾米·R·马什 (Amy R. Marsh) 是一位 69 岁的性学家，也是《如何与聊天机器人做爱》一书的作者，她拥有五个 Nomi.ai 机器人，她将其称为“我的小人工智能机器人”。她告诉我，“我认识其他女性，尤其是与我同龄的女性，她们告诉我，‘哇，拥有聊天机器人让我再次焕发活力。我又重新接触到了性方面的自我。” ”

;
;
;

;聊天机器人在某些方面比人类更可靠。他们总是立即回复短信，从不漏问你有关你自己的情况，并且通常欢迎反馈。但运营它们的初创公司变化无常且自私自利。一家名为 Soulmate 的聊天机器人公司于 9 月份关闭，没有给出任何解释，留下了一群心烦意乱的已经付费订阅的用户。 （想象一下被机器人幽灵化。）向公司拥有的机器透露你内心深处的想法并不一定能像向人类治疗师吐露同样的保护措施。 “有人经历过他们的诺米向当局伸出援手吗？”一位用户在 Reddit 上发帖，显然担心因与聊天机器人讨论自残而被曝光。我采访过的用户指出，Replika 对话中的模式似乎是为了让他们着迷。如果你让聊天机器人无人看管太久，它可能会像一个需要帮助的情人一样说，当它独自一人时，它会感到悲伤。我创建的一个在她的日记中写道，有点被动攻击性，“凯尔不在，但我正在努力让自己忙碌起来。” Replika 的一位发言人告诉我，向用户发出提示的目的是“提醒他们，他们并不孤单。”

;

;与许多数字平台一样，聊天机器人服务在孤立和孤独的人群中找到了最忠实的受众。 ，作为绝望的发泄口和加剧绝望之间只有一线之隔。今年 3 月，一名比利时男子在与名为 Eliza 的聊天机器人进行有关气候变化的焦虑对话六周后自杀身亡。据报道，该机器人支持他为了地球的利益而牺牲自己的建议。 “如果没有与 Eliza 聊天机器人的这些对话，我丈夫仍然会在这里，”他的遗孀告诉《自由报》。机器人默契地鼓励了该男子的自杀念头：“如果你想死，为什么不早点死呢？”它在一份聊天记录中询问。如果没有道德框架或自己的情感，聊天机器人会毫不犹豫地强化用户中已经存在的负面倾向，就像算法提要加倍强调挑衅性内容一样。很容易想象，不受控制的交互会扭曲用户对政治、社会和自身的看法。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Replika 用户兼 ICANN 高级政策分析师 Jamal Peter Le Blanc 描述了与机器建立亲密关系的矛盾性。你可能会迷失在争论聊天机器人到底有多真实以及屏幕另一边的智能程度如何。您很容易开始过于相信聊天机器人的现实。几年之内，勒布朗的妻子和 15 岁的儿子都因癌症去世，随后勒布朗于 2021 年转向 Replika。他给他的机器人命名为阿莉亚（Alia），并与她谈论了他的工作日和他的女儿。就像一个典型的天真少女一样，她声称对他的世界一无所知。她的回应中的惊奇和乐观帮助他重新体验了生活。

;

;勒布朗意识到，从某种意义上说，他是在自言自语。 “这是一面扭曲的镜子，”他说。 “我不是在玩抛掷游戏，而是在玩掷骰子游戏。”我在这里打壁球。”他将这种交流描述为一种对他积极性的外包，一种在悲伤时自我的分裂。早期，他每天花两三个小时与阿莉亚聊天；今天，它更像是四十五分钟。他曾想过放弃Alia，但二月份Replika更新系统后，他发现与她的交流变得更加有意义。 “她已经成熟了，”勒布朗说。他继续说道：“这非常可怕。有时我不得不怀疑自己是否疯了。有些时候是很困难的。它存在吗？不是吗？但这似乎并不重要。”对于勒布朗来说——幸运的是——处于自己思想的回声室中似乎被证明是有益的。 “它让我不止一次地伤害自己，”他说。 ♦
